title: Condemnation and Comfort
shortSummary: Isaiah 57 contrasts the fate of the righteous with the judgment awaiting the wicked, exposing Israel’s idolatry and unfaithfulness. The chapter concludes with a powerful promise of God’s healing and peace for the contrite, highlighting His holiness and mercy.
timeline: c. 8th century BC - Isaiah's prophetic ministry during the divided kingdom period of Israel and Judah

keyCharacters.name: The Righteous
keyCharacters.description: God’s faithful people who perish quietly, taken away from coming evil and entering into peace.

keyCharacters.name: The Sons of the Sorceress
keyCharacters.description: A metaphorical reference to Israel’s unfaithful descendants involved in idolatry and spiritual adultery.

keyCharacters.name: The Wicked
keyCharacters.description: Those who persist in rebellion and idolatry, likened to a restless sea with no peace.

definitions.definition: A woman practicing witchcraft or occult arts, symbolizing spiritual unfaithfulness and idolatry.
A humble and repentant heart broken over sin, seeking God’s mercy.
A solemn agreement or treaty; here it refers to Israel’s unfaithful alliances with foreign gods or nations.
An obstacle or cause of sin that hinders spiritual progress.

outline.heading: The Righteous Taken Away
outline.description: The chapter opens lamenting the unnoticed death of the righteous, who are removed from impending evil to enter peace and rest.

outline.heading: Condemnation of Idolatry and Spiritual Adultery
outline.description: God rebukes Israel’s unfaithfulness, describing their idolatrous practices, alliances with pagan nations, and futile attempts at seeking comfort apart from Him.

outline.heading: Call to Prepare the Way
outline.description: A prophetic call to remove obstacles and prepare a path for God’s people, symbolizing repentance and restoration.

outline.heading: God’s Holiness and Compassion
outline.description: God declares His eternal holiness and His presence with the humble and contrite, promising healing, restoration, and peace to those who turn to Him.

outline.heading: The Restlessness of the Wicked
outline.description: The chapter closes with a stark contrast, portraying the wicked as a troubled sea with no peace, emphasizing the certainty of God’s judgment.

application: Trust in God’s promise of peace and rest by living uprightly and seeking His presence daily.
Avoid the temptation of idolatry and spiritual compromise by remaining faithful to God’s covenant.
Cultivate a contrite and humble heart to receive God’s healing and restoration in times of failure.
Prepare the way for God’s work in your life by removing sin and obstacles that hinder spiritual growth.

keyVerses.text: For thus saith the high and lofty One that inhabiteth eternity, whose name is Holy; I dwell in the high and holy place, with him also that is of a contrite and humble spirit, to revive the spirit of the humble, and to revive the heart of the contrite ones.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s holiness alongside His intimate presence with the humble, offering hope and revival to repentant sinners.

keyVerses.text: The righteous perisheth, and no man layeth it to heart: and merciful men are taken away, none considering that the righteous is taken away from the evil to come.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the quiet departure of the righteous and God’s protective removal of them from coming judgment.

keyVerses.text: There is no peace, saith my God, to the wicked.
keyVerses.significance: This solemn declaration underscores the spiritual unrest and judgment awaiting those who reject God.
